et: Middle English, "poultry organs and body parts used for food, poultry refuse," borrowed from Anglo-French {it}*garbage{/it} (implied in {it}sergant garbagere{/it} "kitchen servant tasked with plucking and cleaning poultry"), of obscure origin

On morphological, semantic, or chronological grounds unlikely to be related to Anglo-French {it}garbeler,{/it} Middle English {it}garbelen{/it} "to remove (impurities) from spices" (see {et_link|garble:1|garble:1}) or to Middle French {it}gaburge, grabuge{/it} "quarrel, brawl." The Anglo-French collocation {it}sergant garbagere{/it} indicates currency of the word as early as 1318 (Household Ordinances of Edward II).
